Container.Name: GitLab CE
Container.Overview:
GitLab Community Edition is a software development collaboration tool.[br][br] This software let's you commit and pull changes from a shared repository.[br] First time this docker boots and you hit the login page, you will be asked to reset a passowrd.[br] Reset it, this is the login for the root account.[br][br]
[span style=\'color: #E80000;\']Docker run Example:[br] [/span] docker run --detach \ --hostname gitlab.example.com \ --publish 84:84 --publish 24:24 \ --name gitlab \ --restart always \ --hostname your.domain.org \ --volume /srv/gitlab/config:/etc/gitlab \ --volume /srv/gitlab/logs:/var/log/gitlab \ --volume /srv/gitlab/data:/var/opt/gitlab \ --env GITLAB_OMNIBUS_CONFIG="gitlab_rails['trusted_proxies']=['192.168.0.20']; \ gitlab_rails['gitlab_shell_ssh_port'] = 24; nginx['listen_port']=84; \ nginx['listen_https']=false;" gitlab/gitlab-ce:latest[br] [br] gitlab.rb template:[br] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/omnibus-gitlab/blob/master/files/gitlab-config-template/gitlab.rb.template[br] Use the Omnibus Config variable to set custom parameters as defined in the gitlab.rb template.
Tested and working behind a reverse nginx proxy using https. Note the ExtraParams in the hostname parameter, this is important. This is needed for the reverse proxy, use your domain name here instead of external url omnibus varaible. Since the external url can not be set if you are not using https, this is the work around. When no external url is set, the project clone urls are created from the container hostnamne. So this is why you have to set the container hostname when using the docker behind a reverse proxy.
